article.headline: PayPal CEO says corporate activism can help spur the âtipping pointâ that brings social change
article.body: An earlier version of this story incorrectly stated PayPalâs stock move for the year. The stock is up 55% on a year-to-date basis. PayPal Chief Executive Dan Schulman Patrick T. Fallon/Bloomberg PayPal Holdings Inc. Chief Executive Dan Schulman argues that corporations have a key role to play in reaching the âtipping pointâ that can bring about social change. The payment technology company announced earlier in June that it was committing $530 million toward helping minority-owned businesses. PayPalâs PYPL, +2.18% Â commitment includes grants to and investments in Black-owned and minority-owned businesses. Schulman said that the grant money is crucial because Black businesses routinely face higher hurdles to traditional loan opportunities, according to a recent interview with CNET. âEven during good times, the amount of financing they can raise, whether it be equity financing or just loans, is much lower than the national average,â he said. âBut in this time, itâs practically impossible for them to get a loan.â Schulman said that PayPal has already disbursed $10 million in grants, not loans, as part of the program. Read: Venmo and Squareâs Cash App were going gangbusters before the pandemic â now theyâre doing even better While the company doesnât have an end date for when it plans to have disbursed its entire $530 million commitment, Schulman said that PayPal wants to âstart moving on it ASAPâ while at the same time making sure there are funds remaining over a longer span. âSome of it [is] more short term-oriented, but we also put in place a very substantial amount of money to help over the long term, because at some point, the marches start to fade away, but the problem still exists,â he said. PayPal is focused on âmultiyear commitmentsâ beyond one-time grants, according to Schulman. In Schulmanâs view, the pandemic has given people more time to reflect on racial issues in the U.S., allowing them to â[tap] into the consciousness of the country,â though thereâs more work to be done. âI think the key is to take advantage of this moment, whether it be nonprofits, organizations that fight for social justice, and the private sector to really step up, because I think things need to start tipping and then they hit a tipping point and then they keep moving,â he said. He stated that people need to âdo more than just condemn racism.â Instead, they need to be âantiracist,â which to him means that they âhave to be a part of the fight.â PayPal had taken a stand on social issues in the past, banning social-network site Gab.com from using its services due to the presence of hateful speech on the Gab platform leading up to the 2018 shooting at a Pittsburgh synagogue. PayPalâs Schulman has argued that the companyâs broader mission has a social component as well since PayPalâs digital financial tools can make money management easier for those without traditional bank accounts. PayPalâs stock has gained 55% year to date, while the S&P 500 index SPX, +0.87% Â has slipped 5.8%.
